Argument.df: a connected series of statements designed to convince an audience of another statement

Artificial.df: A language that was consciously developed by identifiable individuals for some purpose.

Cogent.df: A property of arguments that holds when the argument is strong and the premises are true.

Conclusion.df: the statement that an argument is trying to convince an audience of.

Consistency.df: A property possessed by a set of sentences when they can all be true at the same time, but are not necessarily so.

Contingent.df: A statement that is neither a tautology nor a contradiction.

Contradiction.df: A statement that must be false, as a matter of logic.

Deductive.df: A style of arguing where one attempts to use valid arguments.

Explanation.df: A kind of reasoning where reasons are used to provide a greater understanding of something that is already known.

Formal logic.df: A way of studying logic that achieves content neutrality by replacing parts of the arguments being studied with abstract symbols. Often this will involve the construction of full formal languages.

Inconsistency.df: A property possessed by a set of sentences when they cannot all be true at the same time, but they may all be false at the same time.

Inductive.df: A style of arguing where one attempts to use strong arguments.

Invalid.df: A property of arguments that holds when the premises do not force the truth of the conclusion. The opposite of valid.

Logic.df: the part of the study of reasoning that focuses on argument.

Valid.df: A property of arguments where it is impossible for the premises to be true and the conclusion false

Truth Value.df: The status of a statement with relationship to truth. In our context, this means the status of a statement as true or false

Premise.df: a statement in an argument that provides evidence for the conclusion
